author: News Staff
title: Some members of the deaf cast of ‘Spring Awakening’ visit ‘Stomp’ and see similarities
text:
by Mark Kennedy, The Associated Press Posted Oct 23, 2015 5:18 pm   6:00 pm EDT 
NEW YORK, N.Y. – One of the loudest, rhythmic shows in New York welcomed some special guests this week — cast members from the new Broadway revival of “Spring Awakening,” including some of its deaf actors. 
“Stomp” invited five of the Broadway actors and their friends to Wednesday night’s performance downtown, a gesture the “Spring Awakening” cast has reciprocated. 
Both casts rely on each other for much of their show’s punch — the percussive grooves of “Stomp” and the way “Spring Awakening” integrates deaf and hearing actors into a story about the dangers of failing to communicate. 
“We got to stay after the show and talk with some of the cast and just get an idea of what their process is like,” said Daniel Durant, who plays Moritz and is deaf. “Everyone agreed that we notice those similarities — being really, really unified onstage and being constantly aware of each other’s movement. That allowed us to bond.” 
Durant, using American Sign Language that was translated by his fiancee, Bridget Mitchell, said he didn’t know what to expect when he visited the Orpheum Theater. “Stomp” starts simply enough, with a lone performer sweeping the stage, but builds into a rambunctious frenzy of rhythm. 
Over the course of 90 minutes, “Stomp” performers press everyday objects — lighters, garbage cans, basketballs, poles, buckets, massive oil drums — into percussive service as they dance. 
“When they started with the broom, I didn’t realize until I started picking up the movement that they were doing visual patterns. I did feel a little bit of the vibrations but not quite,” said Durant, who attended with another deaf “Spring Awakening” performer, Russell Harvard, who has appeared on the TV show “Fargo.” 
“When they picked up the percussion and things got, I imagine, louder, I could feel the vibrations and then it was even more incredible. I’ve never laughed so much in a theatrical experience as an audience member,” Durant added. 
Durant is making his Broadway debut and hopes he can find more roles, especially in a town that welcomes fresh, new talent with theatre tickets to other shows. 
“I love the work that I do and any opportunity that I get, I will be happy to continue this work. I love sharing this art and very thankful to be in this position,” he said.
